awd_titl_txt: CNH:   Indigenous Fire Regimes, Land-Use Ecology, and Contemporary Livelihoods in Northern California
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the longest standing and most sweeping effects of humans on natural systems in fire-prone areas has likely been intentional wildfire: people burning natural grasslands and woodlands on purpose.  Within North America, intentional wildfire has almost certainly been widespread for over 5,000 years in what is now California, and may have changed the ecology and driven the evolution of species in woodlands in ways that in turn affect the ability of people to obtain natural resources.  This project will measure direct effects of indigenous burning practices on woodlands and low-elevation, mixed forests in the Central Valley, Klamath Mountains, and Sierra Nevada, and indirect effects of these practices on the availability of wild foods and materials used by indigenous peoples that inhabit the woodlands. Researchers will quantify differences in plant species composition between areas burned by local groups of Native Americans and areas subject to fire suppression, and test effects of burning practices on the regeneration of oaks that dominate the woodlands and on infestation of their acorns by insects.  Detailed studies of time required to harvest and process foods and materials such as stems for construction of household items will show whether burning does in fact improve resource availabilities for people.  This work will take a scientific look at a potentially very important interplay between humans and nature that has been the subject of intensive debate but little quantitative study.

The project personnel will collaborate with tribal and other land managers to develop a better understanding of how to manage fire to achieve social goals and to restore and maintain natural systems. As currently managed, much of California's oak woodlands and low-elevation conifer forests ecosystems are under a threat of high-intensity, destructive wildfires. These ecosystems may in fact be adapted to frequent, low-intensity fires that burn off understory debris, increase species diversity, and reduce the threat of future wildfires.  The project will disseminate findings to tribal and federal agencies.

por.por_cntn:
Fire has become a serious land management concern in California as land management agencies attempt to deal with the century-long legacy of suppressing fires in ecosystems that were adapted to frequent burns. Beyond devastating and costly mega-fires that result from built-up fuels, California is also experiencing more subtle environmental crises as a result of fire exclusion. These may include issues ranging from species loss resulting from decreased habitat diversity to catastrophic oak die-offs occurring across the state. Many of these environmental issues may derive not only from the suppression of lightning and accidental ignitions, but also from the removal of frequent low-intensity fires lit by Native Californians. Research suggests that these traditional fires were smaller, but generally more frequent than climate-driven wildfires. As a result, these native fires may have increased habitat heterogeneity crucial to ecosystem function and reduced pathogens that negatively affect tree species. While these fires may have had a significant impact on California’s environment, to date we have very little quantitative data about the environmental impacts traditional fire-use had across the region. Understanding these patterns is critical for conservation efforts aimed at re-introducing fire in order to restore California’s ecosystems.

In order to help understand these dynamics, this exploratory project examined the role of Native American fire regimes in three California ecosystems. Specifically, we investigated the dynamic links between traditional indigenous burning practices and contemporary Tribal resource use in California across three field sites: the Klamath, Central Valley and Sierra Nevada, working respectively with Karuk and Yurok, Miwok, and Mono Tribal members. We formed an innovative partnership with local Tribes, the US Forest Service, and conservation agencies to conduct collaborative research, education, and ecological restoration on both public and private lands. In each region, researchers undertook extensive ecological monitoring of vegetation under different burn regimes, observational data on resource utility and spatial modeling of long-term effects of traditional burning practices. This provided novel insights into the motivations driving traditional burning practices and the effects these fires had on diverse ecosystems.

Our research efforts focused on oak woodlands, and the role that Native fire plays in fostering oak health and acorn productivity. We found that the type of fire Native knowledge prescribes for oak woodlands in all three regions, low intensity understory fires in the fall, reduces pest loads in acorn crops by destroying infested nuts underneath the tree. This increases the economic efficiency of nut collection in the short term and in the long term, may reduce pest loads on the tree, increasing the acorn crop. Results from both the Sierra Nevada and the Klamath region show that fall fires lit in black oak (Quercus kelloggii) understory prior to collecting acorns would produce an immediate increase in harvesting efficiency by clearing ground cover and reducing the number of infested nuts that require culling. Long-term acorn productivity also increases significantly with greater levels of anthropogenic disturbance, suggesting that repeated fires in black oak groves would increase future harvesting yields. In 2013, project personnel conducted one of the largest prescribed burns in the Central Valley at the Cosumnes River Preserve, and the only one in the state of this size to be conducted by local Tribal (Plains Miwok) representatives. The results of this burn relative to its ecosystem effects are still being monitored.
